574. Cates Catherine Esther (Mrs. Charles William)
It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the question.

Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in western Canada for 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)

Every little except that some friends who had lived near our Manitoba home were living in Okotoks. We were called South Okotoks then, and the school was called Okotoks Point. It was named after a point.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They thought it was an adventure because we were going west and exploring new places.

12. Did you travel with a party (family, friends or other group)? Yes, we traveled with a group of friends.

13. What means of transportation did you use? We took the CPR train to South Pasco, Washington.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences, etc.) We had a long journey which seemed endless. The meeting with the two friends who were getting married in South Pasco was very special.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? We stayed at a friend's house until we found work.

16. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. We moved to British Columbia.

17. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? Teaching then farming at Bonnifield.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far?

My husband's family usually went to church. The vehicle was always filled with people from Brandon and two horses pulled from church. You used horse and buggy or cutter, also a dray buggy. Also drove to Delapelle occasionally. Sometimes went more often to Red Deer. Visits to Valhalla & Kinneighly C.R.C. Often to 1916 pleasure excursions & to Appelle, Indian Head, & other places.
